text: The pronouncement that the prophet Habakkuk perceived.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long, Lord, must I cry out for help,
but you won’t listen?
I’m crying out to you, ‘Violence!’
    but you aren’t providing deliverance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why are you forcing me to look at iniquity
    and to stare at wickedness?
Social havoc and oppression are all around me;
    there are legal conflicts, and disputes abound.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, the Law has become paralyzed,
    and justice never comes about.
Because criminals outnumber the righteous,
    whenever judgments are issued, they come out crooked.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look out at the nations and pay attention!
    Be astounded! Be really astounded!
Because something is happening in your lifetime
    that you won’t believe, even if it were described down to the smallest detail.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Watch out! For I am bringing in the Chaldeans,
    that cruel and impetuous people,
who sweep across the earth
    dispossessing people from homes not their own.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are terrible and fearsome;
    their brand of justice and sense of honor derive only from themselves!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their horses are swifter than leopards,
    and more cunning than wolves that attack at night.
Their horsemen are galloping
    as they approach from far away.
They swoop in like ravenous vultures.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They all come to oppress—
    hordes of them, their faces pressing onward—
they take prisoners as numerous as the desert sand!
speaker: Narrator

text:
They make fun of kings,
    deriding those who rule.
They laugh at all of the fortified places,
    constructing ramps to seize them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then like the wind sweeping by
    they will pass through—
they’re guilty because they say their power is their god.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Haven’t you existed forever,
    Lord my God, my Holy One?
        We won’t die!
Lord, you’ve prepared them for judgment;
    Rock, you’ve sentenced them to correction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your eyes are too pure to gaze upon evil;
    and you cannot tolerate wickedness.
So why do you tolerate the treacherous?
    And why do you stay silent
        while the wicked devour those who are more righteous than they are?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You have fashioned mankind like fish in the ocean,
    like creeping things that have no ruler.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The adversary captures them with a hook,
    gathering them up in a fishing net.
He collects them with a dragnet,
    rejoicing and gloating over his catch.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore he sacrifices to his fishing net,
    and burns incense in the presence of his dragnet,
because by them his assets increase
    and he gets plenty of food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is he to continue to empty his fishing net?
    Will he ever stop killing entire nations without mercy?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will stand at my guard post
and station myself on a tower.
I will wait and see what the Lord will say about me
    and what I will answer when he reprimands me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he answered, the Lord told me: 
“Write out the revelation,
    engraving it clearly on the tablets,
        so that a courier may run with it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the revelation pertains to an appointed time—
    it speaks truthfully about the end.
Though it delays, wait for it,
    because it will surely come about—
        it will not be late!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Notice their arrogance—
    they have no inward uprightness—
        but the righteous will live by their faith.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moreover, just as wine leads astray the proud and powerful man,
    he remains restless;
he has expanded his appetite—
    like the afterlife or death itself, he is never satisfied.
He gathers to himself all of the nations,
    taking captive all of the people for himself.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Will not all of these ridicule him
    with mocking scorn? They will say,
‘Woe to the one who hordes for himself what isn’t his.
    How long will you enrich yourself by extortion?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Won’t your creditors revolt unexpectedly?
    Won’t those who make you tremble wake up?
        As a result, you’ll become their prey!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because you plundered many nations,
    all of their remnants will plunder you.
Human blood has been shed,
    and violence has been done to the land,
        to the city, and to all who live in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Woe to the one who amasses profit upon unjust profit
    in order to establish his household,
so he can establish a secure place on the heights
    and escape from the power of evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have brought shame to yourself by killing many people—
    you are forfeiting your own life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, the stone will cry out from the wall
    and the rafter will respond from the woodwork.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Woe to the one who founds a city upon bloodshed,
    and constructs a city by lawlessness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it not because of the Lord of the Heavenly Armies
    that people grow tired putting out fires,
        and nations weary themselves over nothing?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, the earth will be filled
    with knowledge of the glory of the Lord,
        as water fills the sea.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Woe to the one who supplies his neighbor with a drink!
    You are forcing your bottle on him,
        making him drunk so you can see them naked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are filled with dishonor instead of glory.
    So go ahead, drink and be naked!
    The Lord will turn against you,
    and utter disgrace will debase your reputation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, the violence done to Lebanon will overtake you,
    and the destruction of the beasts will terrorize you—
because you shed human blood
    and did violence to the land, to the city, and to all who live in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where is the benefit in owning a carved image,
    that motivates its maker to carve it?
It is only a cast image—
    a teacher that lies—
because the engraver entrusts himself to his carving,
    crafting speechless idols.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Woe to the one who says to a tree, ‘Wake up!’
    or ‘Arise!’ to a speechless stone.
Idols like this can’t teach, can they?
    Look, even though it is overlaid with gold and silver,
        there’s no breath in it at all.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord is in his holy Temple.
    All the earth—be quiet in his presence.”
speaker: Narrator

text: A prayer by the prophet Habakkuk, set to music.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lord, as I listen to what has been said about you,
    I am afraid.
Lord, revive your work throughout all of our lives—
    reveal yourself throughout all of our lives—
when you are angry,
    remember compassion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God comes from Teman—
    the Holy One from Mount Paran.
 Interlude
His glory spreads throughout the heavens,
    and praises about him fill the earth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Before him pestilence walks,
    and disease follows behind him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He stood up and shook the land;
    with his stare he startled the nations.
The age-old mountains were shattered,
    and the ancient hilltops bowed down. 
His ways are eternal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I saw the tents of Cushan in distress,
    and the tent curtains of the land of Midian in anguish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Was the Lord displeased with the rivers?
    Was your anger directed against the watercourses
        or your wrath against the sea?
Indeed, you rode upon your horses,
    upon your chariots of deliverance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your bow was exposed,
    and your arrows targeted by command.
 Interlude
        You split the earth with rivers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the mountains looked upon you, they trembled;
    the overflowing water passed by,
the ocean shouted,
    and its waves surged upward.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
You march through the land in righteous indignation;
    you tread down the nations in anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You marched out to deliver your people,
    to deliver with your anointed.
You struck the head of the house of the wicked;
    you stripped him naked from head to foot.
 Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
With his own lances you pierced the heads of his warriors,
    who came out like a windstorm to scatter us—
        their joy is to devour the afflicted who are in hiding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You rode on the sea with your horses,
    even riding the crested waves of mighty waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I heard and I trembled within.
    My lips quivered at the noise.
My legs gave way beneath me,
    and I trembled. 
Nevertheless, I await the day of distress
    that will dawn on our invaders.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
as for me, I will rejoice in the Lord.
    I will find my joy in the God who delivers me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord God is my strength—
    he will make my feet like those of a deer,
        equipping me to tread on my mountain heights.
speaker: Narrator
